Anime NYC 2025 - Post-Show Field Report
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

Anime NYC 2025 has come and gone so quickly! Every year, we have to wait till Anime NYC arrives again and begin to prepare. We grab our notepads, think about how to tackle all thatâ€™s within the convention halls, and ready our wallets to be emptied by the merchandise weâ€™ll buy and the food weâ€™ll devour! Itâ€™s hard not to feel like, when this convention finally starts, itâ€™s over in the blink of an eye... That being said, we attended 4 days of Anime NYC 2025 and had quite a few experiences, some good and others bad, and thatâ€™s why we once more present to you all our post-show field report to entertain you! Read all about our various trials and tribulations, as well as some of the shining moments of this yearâ€™s Anime NYC! Now, letâ€™s relive Anime NYC 2025!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

While the prices have risen pretty dramatically, Anime NYC 2025 was larger than previous years and had a lot more events and big name guests. The prices might be a bit hard to stomach for some but again, it was kind of unavoidable.

Company/Event Message for Fans/Attendees

â€œAnime NYC is a creation of LeftField Media, an event company made of dedicated fans and convention organizers. Anime NYC is built with tremendous support from Crunchyroll and publishers across the Japanese pop culture industry.â€

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

What Anime NYC 2025 Did Better Than Before

In comparison to 2024, Anime NYC 2025 had a lot more to explore. There were plenty of booths, from VTUBERS such as Hololive, where fans of various VTUBERs could join together, sing with them, listen to their randomness, and just enjoy a dedicated gaming hall where various tournaments were being held, like Tekken 8, Street Fighter 6, and even Super Smash Bros! Famous YouTubers like IronMouse and CDAWG VA were there too (sadly, we couldnâ€™t watch them due to time constraints), and that was pretty neat! There were also a slew of popular voice actors out there for meetups, interviews, and fan questions. Needless to say, this Anime NYC was without a doubt the most varied one to date. Regardless of what type of otaku you are, Anime NYC 2025 had you covered! There were plenty of booths this year, ensuring a bit more variety than past outings. There was the Hololive stage, where fans of various VTUBERs could join their favorites, sing with themâ€”they performed numerous anime and popular English songsâ€”listen to them talk about silly topics, and even join in as if they were part of the group! Almost every day, Hololive was the loudest event by far, showing just how passionate those fans are. Those who wanted a more typical anime con affair could scour the floors for merchandise from numerous vendors, like Yen Press, Good Smile Company, Viz Media, and plenty of others. But with how pricey Anime NYC 2025 was, this certainly would stretch your savings a bit. Weâ€™d be lying if we didnâ€™t admit we got a ton of figures ourselves, but it was well worth it to show our support to our favorite vendors. Gaming otaku werenâ€™t left in the dark at Anime NYC 2025! There was a big emphasis on games this year, with an entire floor dedicated to hosting gaming events. Con-goers could play against others in their favorite fighting games like Tekken 8, Street Fighter 6, and even Super Smash Bros! There were also card game tables for all the favorites, like Magic the Gathering, Yu-Gi-Oh, and so on. We even heard that some popular YouTubers like IronMouse and CDawgVA were playing games with the crowd! Due to time constraints, we couldnâ€™t see them ourselves, but from the fan roars, we know they were enjoying the event! Lastly, there were quite a few panels and voice actor meetups available! Famous voice talent like Kaiji Tang, Christopher Sabat, Aleks Le, AMALEE, and others were there to talk to con-goers, sign merch, or take photos! There were also plenty of panels where con-goers could learn more about numerous industry themes and/or upcoming projects. It would be impossible to see and experience everything in one day, let alone four, but at the very least, you couldnâ€™t say there was nothing to do at Anime NYC 2025!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

What Anime NYC 2025 Could Have Done Slightly Better

Unfortunately, Anime NYC 2025 wasnâ€™t without its drawbacks. The firstâ€”and most glaringâ€”was overcrowding. We here at Honeyâ€™s Anime have been to our fair share of conventions, large and small, and Anime NYC 2025 is a medium-sized one compared to the titan that is Anime Expo. Nevertheless, it was clear that there was either no limit on how many could attend or a false expectation of how many would show up. Lines affected almost everything at the con, from food stalls and vendors to meeting some of the guests. The lines for food stalls were so long at times that they spilled into the non-food vendor areas, which was just terrible. Equally, seeing some of the guests was a nightmare, as lines could go on so long that it would be either impossible to meet themâ€”unless you were there early enoughâ€”or by the time you worked your way up to the guest, they were on break or done with their time slot. Seriously, Anime NYC 2026 needs to consider capping ticket amounts or opening more of the Javits Center so thereâ€™s more room. Another issue was the lack of big gaming vendors. Despite scouring the floor, we really only saw a few minor ones. Donâ€™t get us wrongâ€”we were more than thrilled to see Honor of Kings with their Detective Conan collaboration and Kaiju No.8, which we could play brieflyâ€”it looks and plays incredibly well for a mobile/Steam game. Yet, we were expecting some bigger gaming panels, maybe from Capcom or even SEGA. We get that this is an anime convention, but it does have a lot of gamers who attend, and we would have liked some more gaming content.

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

Cosplay Was Amazing, Once Again

As you can see, there was a lot of cosplay, but we always try to look for the more unique ones. In our gallery, there are the usual cosplayers, but we are very happy to include some funny and stylish ones from Anime NYC 2025! All cosplayers who had individual photos taken were asked for permission beforehand, so thank you all for posing for Honeyâ€™s Anime! Hopefully next year weâ€™ll see even more from newer anime airing!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
Anime NYC 2025 was great despite some issues here and there. In our opinion, more people attending shows a greater appreciation for the convention, which is wonderfulâ€”but it also means that more of the Javits Center should be opened to help remedy the crowd. All things considered, we had a great time and would love to thank Anime NYC 2025 for allowing us the privilege to attend as press once again! We hope to see you all at Anime NYC 2026, which will no doubt happen after the success of this year! For now, though, weâ€™re going to rest our tired wings and take a much-deserved napâ€¦ [author author_id="078" author="" translator_id=""] [ad_bottom class="mt40"]

  • qdopp Inc., the operator of the global novel submission platform Honeyfeed, is pleased to announce that the popular web novel Why Kill? When Witches Can Be Tentacled! by author kazesenken is now officially in development for potential publication in Japan by KADOKAWA CORPORATION.
  • The story gained significant attention within the Honeyfeed community and was eventually picked up by KADOKAWA MF BOOKS. As a result, the project was approved internally to move forward under the Global UGC Publishing Project, part of KADOKAWAâ€™s Global Business Acceleration Program. This initiative aims to discover promising international writers through overseas novel platforms like Honeyfeed.
  • â€œThis announcement marks a new milestone in our mission to connect international authors with Japanese publishers,â€ said Manami Fukunaga, Manager of The Hivemind Literary Agency, a division of qdopp Inc. that represents select Honeyfeed authors. â€œWeâ€™re excited to see kazesenkenâ€™s talent formally recognized and supported within the Japanese publishing industry.â€
  • Further details such as final publication approval, release date, and format will be shared in due course. For now, fans can celebrate the exciting news that Why Kill? is officially in the pipeline for future print development.

    Novel Synopsis

    Misunderstandings - created at a glance, but difficult to get rid of. Two people are caught in the midst of them, fighting to find a place for themselves. For Maribell Schuzen, stumbling upon the Grimoire of Lies meant being labeled as a Witch, a follower of the slain Demon Lord and enemy of the entire world. For Snazzy-chan, a popular streamer and otaku extraordinaire, a new fate has him wrapped up with tentacles. Tentacles, you say? Why, Snazzy is now a jellyfish of all things! â€œBut donâ€™t worry, Snazzy is a gentlemanly jellyfish!â€ Swearing to protect Maribell with all that his little body can do, Snazzy will show the world that keeping a Witch wrapped up is preferable to a dead Witch! Check out the novel here: honeyfeed.fm/novels/3120

    KADOKAWA Group, a comprehensive entertainment company, develops a wide range of businesses such as Publication, Animation, Film, Gaming, Web services, and Education/EdTech. We maximize the value of IP under our strategy â€œGlobal Media Mix with Technologyâ€ which refers to global rollouts of created IP by utilizing technology. Website: group.kadokawa.co.jp/global.

    Honeyfeed is a leading writing platform that empowers authors to create, share, and engage with their original stories. With a vibrant community of readers and writers, Honeyfeed provides an immersive space for storytelling across various genres, including anime and manga-inspired narratives. For more about Honeyfeed, please visit honeyfeed.fm.

item.title: Main Visual and Promotional Video Out Now! Exclusive Worldwide Streaming on Prime Video Begins October 4!
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • SANDA, by Paru Itagaki (creator of BEASTARS), is an unconventional Santa Claus action series set in near-future Japan, where extreme measures are taken to protect children amid a sharp population decline. The anime premieres in Japan on October 3, 2025, with exclusive worldwide streaming on Prime Video beginning October 4 at 2:53 a.m.
  • Today, the main visual and full promotional video were released. The main visual depicts Daikoku Welfare Academy, where protagonist Sanda and his classmates study, with school principal Hifumi Oshibuâ€”who exerts extreme control over the childrenâ€”looming in the background. Santa Claus dramatically bursts through glass, symbolizing hope in a bleak future.
  • The reveal also introduces key characters and cast: Toshihiko Seki voices 92-year-old principal Oshibu, who obsessively clings to youth through repeated full-body plastic surgery, and Hiroaki Hirata plays Saburo Yagiuda, ace of the St. Nick Pursuit Unit dedicated to capturing Santa. Comments from both voice actors are included below.
  • The promotional video, showcasing Science SARUâ€™s dynamic animation, portrays a world where children are tightly controlled and Santa is freed from a curse through wishes. It also features the first voice lines from the newly revealed characters Oshibu and Yagiuda.
  • The opening and ending themes have also been announced. The opening theme, â€œChildlike Adults,â€ is by yama, and the ending theme, â€œDiary,â€ is by Soushi Sakiyama. Comments from both artists are included below.
  • https://youtu.be/PG9F1afLT-Y

    New Characters and Voice Cast Revealed, with Comments!

    Hifumi Oshibu (Voiced by Toshihiko Seki)

    The 92-year-old principal of Daikoku Welfare Academy, where Sanda and his classmates study. Obsessed with youth, he repeatedly undergoes full-body plastic surgery. He has an extreme dislike of adults and goes to abnormal lengths to protect and monitor his studentsâ€™ every move. Comment 1. How did you feel when you were cast as Oshibu in SANDA? And what message do you have for fans looking forward to the series? Of all Paru Itagakiâ€™s works, SANDA was one I was especially interested in. And among her many characters, Hifumi Oshibuâ€™s personality stands out. I approached the role with a fresh mindset to fully capture his unique presence. Please look forward to it! 2. Since this is an action series featuring Santa Claus, is there anything youâ€™d want to ask him for? If Santa Claus were like the one in this series, every Christmas would be far more exciting! But if a real Santa Claus existed, I think Iâ€™d ask him to promise a future where children everywhere can live in safety. Profile Born: Tochigi Prefecture Major roles: Muzan Kibutsuji in Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba, Medama Oyaji in Birth of Kitaro: The Mystery of GeGeGe, and Hansuke Doi in Nintama Rantaro

    Saburo Yagiuda (Voiced by Hiroaki Hirata)

    The ace of the St. Nick Pursuit Unit dedicated to capturing Santa. Twenty years ago, he inflicted a serious injury on Santa Claus. Comment 1. How did you feel when you were cast as Yagiuda in SANDA? And what message do you have for fans looking forward to the series? Although my character only appears partway through the story, I was warmly welcomed and had a great time recording. These days, there arenâ€™t many productions where we go out drinking after recording, but with this one, everyoneâ€™s a heavy drinker, and I got dragged out until late at night every time. Iâ€™m counting on you, Murase! 2. Since this is an action series featuring Santa Claus, is there anything youâ€™d want to ask him for? Although Iâ€™m over 60, Iâ€™m still full of worldly desires. I think Iâ€™d ask Santa to help me become the kind of person who can say, â€œI have nothing more to wish for.â€ Profile Born: August 7, 1963, Tokyo Major roles: Sanji in ONE PIECE, Sha Gojyo in Saiyuki, and Beryl Gardenant in From Old Country Bumpkin to Master Swordsman

    Opening Theme Song

    â€œChildlike Adultsâ€ by yama (Sony Music Labels Inc.)

    Comment from yama

    ã€€ã€€ã€€ What does it mean to be an adult? Simply growing older does not necessarily make you one. Likewise, I do not believe that being young automatically makes someone a child. Silently carrying pain is both weakness and fragility, and facing it alone might be a clumsy way of avoiding reality. I once thought there was virtue in growing older while holding onto that fragility. But in recent years, whether with people close to me or through music, I have gradually begun to open my heart. The line between myself and others has not changed, yet through connecting with others I discover new sides of myself. I do not think of myself as either an adult or a child, but rather believe that people possess both qualities at any age. It is not about clinging to one side or deciding what is right or wrong. I have simply realized that I want to trust someone, and that is also a way of trusting myself. To anyone else who feels caught between the two, I hope this reaches you.

    Ending Theme Song

    â€œDiaryâ€ by Soushi Sakiyama (Sony Music Labels Inc.)

    Comment from Soushi Sakiyama

    Iâ€™m honored to perform the ending theme. I felt a deep connection to Kazushigeâ€™s inner struggle, caught between adulthood and childhood, and I poured those emotions into the song. In a world without clear answers, where each personâ€™s idea of justice collides, the way Kazushige moves forward with so many voices in his heart has moved me time and again. I hope you enjoy the song together with the anime.

    TV Anime SANDA Overview

    Broadcast begins October 3, 2025 in Japan Official X (formerly Twitter): x.com/sanda_anime Official website: sanda.red

    Cast

    Kazushige Sanda: Ayumu Murase Santa Claus: Hiroki Touchi Shiori Fuyumura: Umeka Shoji Ichie Ono: Anna Nagase Hitoshi Amaya: Yuuki Shin Nico Kazao: Misato Matsuoka Hifumi Oshibu: Toshihiko Seki Saburo Yagiuda: Hiroaki Hirata

    Staff

    Original: â€œSANDAâ€ by Paru Itagaki (Akita Shoten / Shonen Champion Comics) Director: Tomohisa Shimoyama Script: Kimiko Ueno Music: Tomoyuki Tanaka (FPM) Character Design & Chief Animation Director: Masamichi Ishiyama Art Director: Miki Higaki Color Design: Saori Goda Compositing Director: Hikari Itoh Editor: Kiyoshi Hirose Sound Director: Keiichiro Miyoshi Animation Production: Science SARU Opening Theme song: â€œChildlike Adultsâ€ by yama Ending Thema song: â€œDiaryâ€ by Soushi Sakiyama

    Original Manga

    Volumes 1 through 16 of Paru Itagakiâ€™s SANDA (published by Akita Shoten under the Shonen Champion Comics label) are now on sale!

item.title: BEYBLADE X US National Tournament Brings Anime-Worthy Duels to Los Angeles Anime Expo 2025
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

TAKARATOMY held its first-ever Beyblade X National U.S. Open-Class Qualifier as part of their BEYBLADE X World Championship 2025, hosted inside the Los Angeles Anime Expo â€• marking 25 years since the brand first arrived in the U.S.! If thatâ€™s not hinting at how exhilarating this contest was, keep on reading!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

A surge of excitement radiated through the Entertainment Hall, and for those attendees who visited, it was common to hear the thrilling chant of â€œ3â€¦ 2â€¦ 1â€¦ Let it RIP!!â€ echoing through the venue. It was an instant attention-grabber for fans young and old who had ever watched the anime or played Beyblade themselves. Impossible to miss, the Beyblade championship arena drew in thousands of spectators over the four days of the convention. On Saturday, July 5, the tournament reached its final stage, attracting 128 competitors who made history by participating in the first official U.S. Open-Class single-elimination showdown.

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

Not only did contestants experience the structure of an official tournament, like those held in Japan, but this was also foreshadowing, as the champion of the U.S. tournament would advance to the Beyblade X World Championship 2025 in Japan, with an all-expenses-paid trip to represent the United States. Honeyâ€™s Anime had the opportunity to sit front row for the final showdown, and trust us when we say the crowd was filled with extreme positivity, immaculate energy, and a raging hype that built up even more each round.

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

Starting with the third-place match, TMS faced Cosmo Dragon, a duel that TMS slayed with a 3-point victory, a survivor finish!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

Next up was Yushwa, cosplaying as Takao Kinomiya, the protagonist of â€œBakuten Shoot Beyblade,â€the first series of the Beyblade anime. His opponent was ElenaBEY, a woman who won the hearts of the crowd thanks to her meme-worthy championship picture. Despite their playful demeanor, the two finalists delivered a seriously intense battle that was just as exciting as duels weâ€™ve seen in the anime!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

This battle was truly worthy of being the last match in the national US championship, it had it all. Mid-air collision, survivor finish, and a double knockout finish you name it! This battle was intense. In the end, ElenaBEYâ€™s trusty Dran Buster 5-60 LF pulled through, helping her make a comeback after a draw and score two points with a knockout to win the championship.

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

The Entertainment Hall erupted with intense cheering for ElenaBEY, who secured her ticket to Tokyo this October for the global finals. But she wasnâ€™t the only one being celebrated. The crowd was going wild for all eight top competitors who delivered thrilling action throughout the day. We had the opportunity to do a quick interview with the top 3, and this is what they had to say:

Interview with TMS, 3rd Place

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
Q: Did you come today with the intention of winning, or just having fun? Did you expect to make it this far? A: I came all the way from Texas to win. I was waiting since 2018 for this moment and the experience was insane; Iâ€™m just really happy to get to compete. Q: How did you hear about this tournament at AX, and was this your first time in a tournament? A: Iâ€™m a content creator who focuses on competitive Beyblade so of course I knew about this and Iâ€™ve been in 32 tournaments just in the past 6 months to make it here. Q: After todayâ€™s defeat, do you plan on changing your strategy? A: I plan to constantly change my style as always, trying out different styles of my interest.

Interview with Yushwa, 2nd Place

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
Q: After such an intense spin-off against ElenaBEY, how do you feel? A: Exhausted! And stressed, but I wanted to make sure people had a good time watching the match. Q: Weâ€™ve noticed you have quite a fan following among the crowd. Do you have a few words to share with your fans? A: SoCal is still strong. We need more tournaments, more opportunities to give a chance to more players. Donâ€™t stop playing until Beyblade becomes an e-sport! Until then, we need to take care of each other. I hope everyone had fun watching my matches and that I could deliver what the crowd wanted to see.

Interview with ElenaBEY, US Champion

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
Q: In a competitive scene like Beyblade X, how do you feel as a woman having won this championship in a game predominantly played by men? A: Now I feel proud to represent women in Beyblade, not only as the U.S. champion. I want to show that Beyblade is for everyone, and I hope my win influences more women to join the world of Bey. Q: Did you come to this tournament focused on winning? A: I never expected to reach the top, or win! My friends helped me out with the knowledge of what Beyblade to pick, they helped me a lot through the preliminaries so I feel this win is for everyone who helped me. I am surprised I won! Q: Were you surprised that the champion would have a chance to trip to Japan to join the BEYBLADE X World Championship 2025? Is this your first time going? A: No, it wasnâ€™t a surprise. People were talking about the chance to compete in the World Championship in Japan. Itâ€™s not my first time in Japan, but Iâ€™m really looking forward to the shopping and food in Tokyo! Q: Any final words for your fans? A: The most important thing is to have fun and keep playing!
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

The Beyblade X National Tournament not only made history in the U.S but also delivered an unforgettable experience to fans and players alike. Tokyo, get readyâ€”passion is on its way from the U.S.

item.title: [Honey's Anime Interview] Goro Taniguchi, Creative Producer for "Enter the Garden", an Anime Series by Azuki and Dentsu
item.content:encoded:
At Anime Expo 2025, Honeyâ€™s Anime sat down with famous director Goro Taniguchi, best known for Code Geass, to talk about his latest experimental work as the creative producer for Enter the Garden, an original anime produced by Azuki in collaboration with Dentsu. Known for its unique blend of American streetwear aesthetics and traditional Japanese visuals, Enter the Garden marks a bold departure from Japanâ€™s traditional anime production model. Taniguchi shared his thoughts on creative freedom, artistic philosophy, and how Azukiâ€™s community is reshaping what it means to create anime.

Goro Taniguchi
Honey-Chan
Interview with Goro Taniguchi
[gray-hex-decoration]
You've worked within the traditional Japanese pipeline of transforming an idea into anime. How has your experience differed working with Azuki, especially given their focus on short-format anime and changing how anime is produced?
In the past, I usually worked with stories that already existed. This time working with Azuki, there was no original material to reference. So the process started with me asking, â€œIs this the right path?â€ and then presenting my ideas to Azuki. Sometimes those ideas were rejected, but the key has been constant communication between us. Iâ€™ve had to understand Azukiâ€™s goals and translate that into animation. This open, cross-partner dialogue is very different from working with Japanese publishers or studios that produce anime, manga, or light novels in a traditional format. So far, itâ€™s been a refreshing and exciting change for me.
Enter the Garden seems to be inspired heavily by modern American street fashion and traditional Japanese elements. Could you tell me more about what inspired the look and aesthetic of the world?
As I mentioned earlier, we first asked the Azuki side to show us what kind of things they were thinking about and wanted to do, as well as what kinds of fan art existed. From there, we picked out the parts of their ideas that we understood or that we also thought were cool. Staff members who understood the concept arranged everything in the form of Episode 1, Episode 2, and Episode 3.
Are there plans to introduce other cultural aspects from different countries in future episodes?
Thatâ€™s something I intentionally avoid. Digging deeper into the reasoning, the staff working on the project had already had that kind of idea in the past; however, we have agreed on focusing on one style identity with room for subtle influences. If I direct that they should include other cultural references, it may hinder the staffâ€™s creativity. Thatâ€™s something I would like to avoid. I believe that giving the team creative freedom yields better results. I purposely place staff who can generate something good without being influenced. To give more details, for episode 1, I assigned staff who had worked on things other than anime. In episode 2, I assigned staff who could also illustrate the 1980s to 2000s eraâ€™s anime style. By doing this, I can ensure each episode has its own uniqueness.
What can you tell me about the characterâ€™s personality? Are they in any way influenced by Azukiâ€™s company philosophy or your vision as a director?
As for episode 1, the world setting is Azukiâ€™s idea but the characters were created under our direction. In episode 2, we featured Azukiâ€™s original characters, but I directed how they came to life on screen. Episode 3, which hasnâ€™t been released yet, both the characters and the world were created as a way to further expand our interpretation of Azuki.
When you talk about expanding in artwork and animation technique, in what way do you mean exactly? Are you talking about introducing techniques like rotoscopying or stop motion animation?
Itâ€™s not about technique for the sake of technique. Itâ€™s about philosophy and how to express an idea visually. If stop motion helps convey that concept, weâ€™ll use it. But technique is secondary to intention. What matters most is expressing the underlying message in a compelling way.
Between episodes 1 and 2 of Enter the Garden, there seems to have been some evolution regarding animation. How did Azuki grow during this process, and what did you learn?
Absolutely, thereâ€™s been growth. Originally, I had my plans for episodes 2 and 3. But after finishing episode 1, Azuki suggested new ideas for episode 2, probably ideas that reflected community feedback. I didnâ€™t see these suggestions as just coming from a company, but as a petition from the fans. So I made adjustments to my original vision. Anime is a business, yes, but itâ€™s also for the fans. Their input helped shape the direction of the project.
What message or experience do you hope to deliver to the anime community with Enter the Garden?
Whatever message I want to convey can only be delivered through the anime itself. Thatâ€™s why I create. What makes this project special is that it listens to the fans and translates their voice into animation. Thatâ€™s what truly matters.
Are you hoping to bring more creators into the Azuki community, or is this anime laying the groundwork for something bigger?
Whether it's from the wide anime community or Azukiâ€™s community, if you are a creator, the more eyes on your work, the better. My goal isnâ€™t just to cater to the Azuki community, itâ€™s to reach the wider anime audience. By doing this, if that draws more people into Azuki, thatâ€™s something I can feel happy about. If that happens, you can say creating Enter the Garden anime was successful.
Working with legends like Tatsuyuki Tanaka on Enter the Garden must be a unique experience. How do you foster an equal creative environment for industry veterans?
The answer is very simple. As the director, I define clear creative boundaries. I explained the project and everyoneâ€™s responsibilities at the start. Mr. Tanaka understood exactly what his role was and where his creative domain lay. Once thatâ€™s clear, I donâ€™t interfere unless someone steps outside their zone. That mutual respect is what keeps the environment clear of issues.
Goro Taniguchiâ€™s approach to Enter the Garden reveals a balance between personal creative vision and open collaboration with both Azuki and its growing community. This experimental project isnâ€™t just about breaking anime conventions in format and production, itâ€™s about exploring how far you can go when fan voices, corporate goals, and experienced direction meet halfway. With more episodes on the horizon and an evolving aesthetic, Enter the Garden may just be a blueprint for a new era of anime production where creators like Taniguchi continue to innovate beyond borders.

[Honey's Anime Interview] Takayuki Miyauchi and Kenta Wakisawa From T-SPARK at the Los Angeles Anime Expo 2025
item.content:encoded:
At Anime Expo 2025 in Los Angeles, Honeyâ€™s Anime had the opportunity to sit down with two key figures driving strategy and innovation in the world of collectible figures and character goods: Takayuki Miyauchi (Senior Assistant Manager of the Marketing Team in the Collector Business Group, Hobby Character Business Division) and Kenta Wakisawa (Assistant Manager of the R&D Team in the same division). In our conversation, Miyauchi-san and Wakisawa-san offered a rare glimpse into the heart of the industryâ€”and how they plan to keep surprising collectors worldwide.

Miyauchi
Wakisawa
Honey-Chan
Interview with the T-SPARK Team
[gray-hex-decoration]
T-SPARK is described as a brand for adult hobbyists. Whatâ€™s the vision behind creating a unified brand for adult hobbyists and has that vision evolved since its launch?
Wakisawa: Our division handles long-running IPs like Transformers and ZOIDS, and weâ€™d already been developing products for a high-target demographic. So under the company-wide policy of increasing lifetime value and expanding customer segments, we decided to take the lead in expanding offerings for kidults (adults with a playful spirit). Although the toy and hobby businesses may seem similar, their structures differ significantly. So for this initiative, we assembled a project team that included members beyond just management and our division. Together, we held in-depth discussions, looking ten years ahead, on how our company should approach and expand the kidult market from a medium- to long-term perspective. Through those discussions, we realized that Takara TOMY now targets a wide spectrum of customers, from children to adults, and that this requires different approaches for each segment in both product development and marketing. In the hobby category especially, we recognized the need to clearly define and separate our kidult offerings. For instance, our official YouTube channel previously featured videos for both kids and adults, but to deliver more relevant content to each audience, shouldnâ€™t we consider separating the channels? There are also differences in focus between childrenâ€™s and adultsâ€™ products when it comes to quality and ethical standards, raising the need for distinct criteria. As we looked to expand the kidult segment over the medium to long term, it became clear that clearer boundaries were needed. That led to the decision to launch a separate label for kidult-focused collector items. This was the rationale behind T-SPARK, and our vision has remained unchanged since its launch.
How do you prepare your marketing strategies to reach its intended audience, particularly in international markets like here in the USA?
Wakisawa: We only began expanding into the U.S. market in 2025, so weâ€™re still in the early stages, testing various strategies to see what works. While overall trends in the U.S. market arenâ€™t drastically different from those in Japan, action figures are a particularly strong category, and in recent years, Japanese IPs have become extremely popular. By leveraging that interest in Japanese culture and applying Takara TOMYâ€™s hobby expertise, we aim to develop new products and build awareness of the T-SPARK brand. Our appearance at AX this time is part of that effort. Looking ahead, we plan to roll out a variety of collaboration products featuring popular manga, anime, and other globally loved content. Weâ€™re also working to strengthen our online presence, centered around our North American e-commerce platform, Tommy Plus. At the same time, we want to create more offline touchpoints, such as places where fans can see product samples in person.
How do you approach targeting adult collectors over younger fans, especially when working with huge titles like My Hero Academia that attract multi-generational audiences?
Miyauchi: We believe that expanding the T-SPARK brand is essential to gaining traction with adult collectors. The new figure brands weâ€™ve launched will offer a wide range of products, from affordable to high-end, designed to appeal to various fan demographics. SPARK Fig is a mid- to high-priced series targeting adult collectors, while the COLLEKAZARO series is designed not only for adult collectors but also to appeal to female fans. By offering a diverse range of products targeting a broad fan base, we hope to raise awareness of the T-SPARK brand among as many people as possible.
Although brief, our conversation with Miyauchi-san and Wakisawa-san shed light on how Takara TOMY is shaping the future of its collector business through T-SPARK, a brand built with a playful spirit, yet crafted with the sophistication and quality adult fans expect. From the long-term vision that led to creating a distinct label, to early steps in expanding into the U.S. market, and the thoughtful strategies behind engaging multi-generational fandoms with lines like SPARK Fig and COLLEKAZARO, itâ€™s clear that T-SPARK represents more than just figuresâ€”itâ€™s a commitment to redefining what it means to collect, connect, and celebrate Japanese pop culture on a global scale.

item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

When King of Seas was first announced, the gaming world was all about pirates. Sea of Thieves, released last year, is a multiplayer experience that started with very little content but now has dozens of things to do and over ten thousand concurrent players. At first, Sea of Thieves and King of Seas were bound to compete, but after a few delays, King of Seas ended up debuting almost a year later. If you ask us, King of Seas is a better pirate game... but that's just us. If you like sea chants, sinking enemy ships, and role-playing as the meanest pirate to ever sail the oceans, here's another game you need to try!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

Honeyâ€™s Anime got the opportunity to try T-ARTSâ€™s Gacha machines, and the process was very simple. First, exchange money for a special token directly at their booth, with prices starting at as low as five dollars per token. Next, browse through their large collection of Gacha machines, each featuring different toy collections from anime like Oshi No Ko, major IPs like Sanrio, or Japanese culture-inspired toys like convenience store snack models and cute Shiba Inu capsule toys. Celebrating its 60th anniversary in Japan in 2025, the Gacha area of the booth also offered visitors a hands-on experience with a free Gacha draw for those who shared their booth experience on social media.

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

But more than the Gacha themselves, we were especially interested in their new blind box collection called â€œPERIHAPI!â€, which they displayed onsite with adorable (and huge!) chibi figures featuring Vocaloid characters and cast members from the anime Haikyu!! We canâ€™t wait for this collectible series to come to stores in the USA.

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

The TOMY booth kept on giving, offering a huge collection of their movable model kits for adult hobbyists brought to us by T-SPARK, the unified brand for TOMY Companyâ€™s hobby products with various series. Q VILLAGE was also there with its sleek line of deformed format vehicle models for Fast and the Furious and the legendary street-racing manga Initial D. The booth also featured a display of the SYNERGENEX crossover collection of Macross 7 Ã— Transformers with Basara Prime model kits. And last but not least, the COLLEKAZARO brand showcased its My Hero Academia fully articulated collectible figures.

ElenaBEY, a First-Year Blader, Wins the BEYBLADE X National Tournament Held in Los Angeles at Anime Expo and Earns a Spot at the World Championship in Japan!
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • On July 5, 2025, TOMY Company, Ltd. held the Open Class (ages 13+) of the BEYBLADE X National Tournament for the BEYBLADE X series (the modern version of â€œbei-gomaâ€ spinning tops) at the BEYBLADE X booth during Anime Expo 2025, North Americaâ€™s largest anime and manga convention.
  • This event was held to determine the top blader from the U.S. tournament who will advance to the BEYBLADE X WORLD CHAMPIONSHIP 2025*, scheduled for October in Japan, the birthplace of Beyblade. On the morning of the event, a crowd of eager participants far exceeding the number of tournament spots gathered at the booth, filling the venue with the passion and energy of US bladers even before the matches began.
  • Before a packed crowd, the closely contested tournament ended with ElenaBEY emerging as the winner. In the finals, she initially conceded a point to Yushua, who scored a â€œSurvivor Finish,â€ but she quickly turned the tables by earning two points of her own. Yushua then caught up, tying the score and turning the match into a fierce, back-and-forth battle. In the end, ElenaBEY sealed her comeback victory with a stunning â€œXtreme Finishâ€ using an Attack-Type Beyblade. The crowd erupted in cheers at the dramatic conclusion, bringing the tournament to an exciting close that perfectly showcased the thrill of BEYBLADE X.
  • After securing her spot at the world championship, ElenaBEY was warmly congratulated by fellow competitors who had battled alongside her. She shared that she began playing Beyblade after a friendâ€™s suggestion. Her victory in Los Angeles, the entertainment capital of the world, inspired many spectators who witnessed it.
  • With its new â€œXtreme Dashâ€ gimmick enabling ultra-acceleration, BEYBLADE X is the fastest in the brandâ€™s history. It has captured the hearts of both players and spectators, gaining popularity worldwide as a form of â€œGEAR SPORTS.â€ Bladers from 20 regions*, are scheduled to compete in the upcoming World Championship, and qualifiers are underway worldwide. Keep an eye out for ElenaBEY as she takes the stage alongside other Bladers who have battled their way to the top. *In some countries, only one division is held, either the Regular Class (ages 6 to 12) or the Open Class (which is also open to adults).

    • Comments From the Top 3

    Winner: ElenaBEY: The friend who introduced me to Beyblade came to the venue today to cheer me on! Iâ€™m already excited to meet Bladers from around the world at the upcoming World Championship in Tokyo. Runner-up: Yushua I missed out on the victory, but my next step is to expand the Beyblade community. I feel that Beyblade is exciting enough to be enjoyed like a sport.â€ 3rd Place: TMS I came all the way from Texas to join this tournament. I was waiting for this moment for several years, and Iâ€™m just really happy to get to compete. I always plan my strategy, and Iâ€™m going to try out different styles that interest me.
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    Alongside the BEYBLADE X National Tournament, the free-play area was set up at the venue during the event, attracting over 3,000 fans who casually enjoyed the Beyblade experience. To make it easier for beginners, Beyblades were available to borrow, and tutorials were offered, attracting a lively crowd of all ages, from children to adults.

    Date: Saturday, July 5, 2025 Time: 4:25 PM â€“ 5:00 PM (Pacific Daylight Time) Location: Los Angeles Convention Center (ENTERTAINMENT HALL - E-25) Official Website: beyblade.com/worldchampionship2025 *Highlights from the tournament will be available to watch on the official BEYBLADE X YouTube channel at a later date.

    BEYBLADE X WORLD CHAMPIONSHIP 2025

    The first-ever world championship for the BEYBLADE X series. Winners from regional tournaments around the world will compete to become the top Blader, with the event also serving as a platform for international exchange. The championship will take place over two days, October 11 and 12, 2025, at the iconic Tokyo Tower in Japan. The tournament will be streamed live globally on the official BEYBLADE X YouTube channel â€œBEYTUBEâ€ and on official regional YouTube channels, delivering the excitement of the event to viewers in real time.

    About BEYBLADE

    â€œBEYBLADEâ€ battling tops, debuted in 1999, are a modernized version of traditional Japanese battling tops known as â€œbei-goma.â€ Over 520 million units have been shipped cumulatively in more than 80 countries and regions around the world (as of April 2023). Each series has created a craze in many countries across the world including Japan. The fourth generation, BEYBLADE X started in July 2023 in Japan. item.title: Six Full-sized Music Videos by Cornelius Featuring Songs from Ghost in the Shell: Arise Now Streaming Online!
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • Cornelius collaborated with various artists and filmmakers to release six full-sized music videos featuring songs from the Ghost in the Shell: Arise series, all of which are now available to stream on major platforms. Corneliusâ€™ cutting-edge musical vision combined with the philosophical talent of these filmmakers pose striking questions for the modern age.
  • Utilizing diverse methods such as animation, live-footage, CG, and physical expression, the videos explore recurring themes from Ghost in the Shell: the uncertainty of existence, the fusion of city and body, and the relationship between humans and technology. The seamless blend of sound and visuals in this collection offers a new experience not only for fans, but for anyone with an interest in musical and visual expression.
  • Corneliusâ€™s interview has also been published on the official Ghost in the Shell global website.

    • Three Years of Expressing a Cyber-Society through Music: The Relationship between Cornelius and Ghost in the Shell

    Find the intervew here: theghostintheshell.jp/news/cornelius-interview Keigo Oyamada, a.k.a Cornelius, produced music for Ghost in the Shell: Arise for three years. He fuses acoustic instruments and electronic sounds to create a vision of a cyber-societal world with â€œthe existence of soulâ€ as the keyword. He talks about using his own style to create the soundtrack and theme song while staying true to the sci-fi nature of the work, and how that influenced his career as a musician.

    Ghost in the Shell: Arise Opening Theme â€œGhost in the Shell: Ariseâ€

    https://youtu.be/jq8iRxA88pk Music: Cornelius Director: Yugo Nakamura This experimental technique uses still images from the anime that are printed and photographed individually against an urban backdrop. The ambiguity of cyborgs is expressed by blending them into the real world.

    Border:1 Ending Theme â€œJibun ga Inaiâ€ by salyu x salyu

    https://youtu.be/ijuSIUKzB24 Lyrics: Shintaro Sakamoto Composition: Keiga Oyamada Director: Koichiro Tsujikawa Performance: Salyu This poetic visual world where bodies and voices overlap in multiple layers explores the space between â€œabsenceâ€ and â€œpresence.â€

    https://youtu.be/oSDRRsj-XQU Lyrics: Shintaro Sakamoto Composition: Keigo Oyamada Director: Koichiro Tsujikawa Through the innocent faces of children, it quietly questions humanity and the loneliness of society as a battlefield.

item.title: fhÃ¡na and Sachiko Kobayashi Celebrate the Release of New Theme Songs for Miss Kobayashiâ€™s Dragon Maid Movie: â€œParade of Tearsâ€ and â€œBokutachi no Hibiâ€
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="Author/Photographer: Junichi Tsukagoshi" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • A special event was held on July 13, in AEON LakeTown mori, to celebrate the release of the new opening and ending songs for the Miss Kobayashiâ€™s Dragon Maid movie!
  • Kyoto Animationâ€™s newest work is a heart-warming tale about family and the bonds that unite us. Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid: A Lonely Dragon Wants to Be Loved is the latest installment in the animated series, which started airing in 2017. Of course, seeing these popular scenes from the original work on the big screen has been a huge hit with the audiences!
  • On July 13th (Sunday), fhÃ¡na and Sachiko Kobayashi made an appearance at AEON LakeTown mori, to help kick off the release of their respective opening and ending songs, â€œParade of Tearsâ€ and â€œBokutachi no Hibi.â€ Since Koshigaya in Saitama Prefecture serves as the storyâ€™s backdrop, the location couldnâ€™t have been more fitting.
  • Tickets for the priority viewing area (which came with the purchase of one of the CDs being released that day) sold out in a flash. The space was packed with spectators before the event even started. Since there might not be enough time during the concert itself, Kevin Mitsunaga (sampler, etc.) gave the crowd a primer on the choreography for â€œParade of Tearsâ€ during their rehearsal, and asked them to lead the rest of the audience for the real deal.

    • About the Event

    The event itself started right at 1:00 p.m., with fhÃ¡naâ€™s performance of one of the definitive opening themes from the anime, â€œRhapsody of Blue Sky.â€ Towana (vocalist) got the audience all fired up as her voice rang out from the stage, accompanied by Junichi Sato on the keyboard, and Kevin on the metallophone. The crowd sang and clapped along, clearly enjoying their amazing pop performance. Pausing just long enough to announce their group name, fhÃ¡na launched straight into â€œLove Supreme!â€, the opening song from Miss Kobayashiâ€™s Dragon Maid S. Towana and Kevinâ€™s bright, bouncy rap makes it a memorable song, and their fast-paced repartee, mingled with the crowdâ€™s applause, created an euphoric atmosphere.
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    During the MC segment, they mentioned that they were pleased to be visiting Koshigaya for the first time. And most people in attendance raised their hands when asked whether or not theyâ€™d seen the Miss Kobayashiâ€™s Dragon Maid movie. On seeing that, Junichi mentioned that their next song had been â€œinspired by Kannaâ€™s (CV. Maria Naganawa) tears.â€ Then, Kevin gave the crowd a quick review of the choreography before launching straight into the movieâ€™s opening theme, â€œParade of Tears.â€ The crowd was quick to put those moves into action when the chorus came around. Though, for an upbeat pop song, thereâ€™s an element of melancholy to it. Since fhÃ¡na has created each of the seriesâ€™ opening songs, their lyrics and melodies have really stuck with the listeners. Junichi joined in the dancing partway through, livening up the performance even furtherâ€”but was probably going to limit that to this event. (Or possibly the upcoming Animelo Summer Live event.) â€Yeah, I think thatâ€™s it for the dancing,â€ he said, mellowing the mood out.
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    This was the perfect transition into the ending themeâ€™s portion of the event. The audience called out for â€œKobayashi-saaan!â€ (just like the titular character), Sachiko Kobayashi took to the stage to sing â€œBokutachi no Hibi.â€ The message there is that â€œNothing is certain, but thatâ€™s easy to forget. We might have met here by accident, but thatâ€™s a kind of miracle. These precious moments ought to be cherished.â€ Standing on stage in her stunning red dress, Sachikoâ€™s gentle voice rang out, instantly catching everyoneâ€™s attention. Her voice couldnâ€™t be better suited to a song that talks about how the â€œusualâ€ things are the foundation of life. The performance was only a few minutes long, but it was a wonderfully moving piece that truly encapsulated the movie. After that touching finale to a rousing mini concert, fhÃ¡na closed out the event by signing CDs that the fans had purchased. Miss Kobayashiâ€™s Dragon Maid: A Lonely Dragon Wants to be Loved is a huge hit! fhÃ¡na and Sachiko Kobayashiâ€™s opening and ending songs have gone on sale to great acclaim! Plus, it was okay to take pictures and videos at this event, so there are probably plenty of those to check out on social media.

item.title: â€œHYPNOSISMIC -Division Rap Battle- Movieâ€& â€œUta noâ˜†Prince-sama TABOO NIGHT XXXXâ€Anime Expo 2025 Screening Report
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • Fans of anime, manga, games and cosplay from all over the world had the opportunity to attend a special double screening from King Records of "HYPNOSIS MIC -Division Rap Battle- Movie" and "Uta noâ˜† Prince-samaâ™ª TABOO NIGHT XXXX" at Anime Expo, the largest anime event in North America.
  • Hereâ€™s our report of the screening held at The Novo on Saturday afternoon!

    • HYPNOSISMIC -Division Rap Battle-

    I arrive at my second-floor front-row seat 15 minutes before showtime. While it doesn't seem too crowded, I look to the first floor front-row seats to see several groups of what appear to be fans in cosplay, checking their penlights. Looking at the screen, I see a QR code to download the app that will be used to determine each battle's winner, as well as how to vote during the screening. This won't be your typical theater experience â€” it's something entirely new, where the outcome of the movie lies in the hands of the audience.
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    "Hypnosis Mic -Division Rap Battle-", or "HypMic" for short, is a story set in a world where armed conflict is illegal, and territory is instead gained via rap battles using Hypnosis Mics, special microphones that interfere with human psyche. Teams representing each division compete in the "Division Rap Battles", led by the all-female team Party of Words. Battles are fought in teams of 3, with 6 teams total: â†’ Buster Bros!!!: Ikebukuro Division â†’ MAD TRIGGER CREW: Yokohama Division â†’ Fling Posse: Shibuya Division â†’ Matenro: Shinjuku Division â†’ Bad Ass Temple: Nagoya Division â†’ DOTSUITARE-HOMPO: Osaka Division
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    The team that wins the first and second stages will proceed to the final stage where they can challenge the Party of Words in battle. The full movie covers events up until the final stage, but for this specially-edited AX closing screening, only up until the second stage is shown. But what sets this movie experience apart is the mid-movie voting, done via a mobile app called CtrlMovie. After each battle's conclusion, a 10-second countdown begins on the app where viewers vote for the best-performing team by tapping the division's logo. After a few seconds, the winning team is displayed and the story continues. As the fate of each team is decided by the audience, even for those who might not call themselves fans, the tension in the room as the countdown begins is electric. As the result flashes on the screen, the audience eruptsâ€”united in a chorus of both joy and heartbreak that reverberates through the theater. The characters' reactions and comments differ depending on the results, which makes every viewing a unique thrill. In total there are a whole 48 different ways the story can play out. Fans will watch them all, no doubt. I realize it's almost time for the movie to start and take a last look around behind me to see that the seats are now filled to overflowing, with even more people standing behind the last row. The first floor is of course also packed. Seeing this spectacle, I feel the excitement building as the MC stirs up the crowd. Then, the screening finally starts. Over the roars of the crowd, the first thing we see are clips introducing each division. Every team is met with screams of excitement, with the waving penlights changing color each time. I now realize that the pre-screening penlight checking was for this all-important color-changing operation. The introductions perfectly capture each team member's characteristics and their relationships with each other. Next is the opening video, where we get to hear everyoneâ€™s singing voices, and includes every character. The battleground is set. The cheers were so loud for every single division that I could not even guess which one might win.
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    And now for the rap battles to begin!

    First stage, first battle

    Buster Bros!!! Vs Bad Ass Temple The battle between Ichiro (Buster Bros!!! leader) and Kuko (Bad Ass Temple leader), who are former teammates, is a must-see. Time for the vote of destiny. After a short silence, Buster Bros!!!â€™s logo appears on the screen, followed by loud cheering and crying. Up on the screen, Kuko approaches Ichiro and they congratulate one another. Fans cheer out warmly.

    First stage, second battle

    MAD TRIGGER CREW Vs DOTSUITARE-HOMPO Samatoki (leader of MAD TRIGGER CREW) and Sasara (DOTSUITARE-HOMPO leader) were also once partners on the same team. They know each other inside out â€” every strength and every weakness. But today isn't a duel. It's a team battle, where the team that unites their strengths to the fullest seizes victory. Voting time again. A few seconds pass in silence before DOTSUITARE-HOMPO's logo flashes onto the screen. The crowd erupts. In the face of his loss, Samatoki speaks gracefully and the crowdâ€™s comforting words left an impression.

    First stage, third battle

    Fling Posse vs Matenro Ramuda (leader of Fling Posse) and Jakurai (Matenro's leader) say they hate one-another, but what is the truth...? During the battle their faces were so close they almost touched, which resulted in cheering and screaming throughout the venue every time. Once again it is time to vote, and after a short silence, Matenro's logo appears and is met with loud cheering and screaming. The resentment between the two leaders fades and Jakurai approaches Ramuda amicably, but Ramuda's irritation at Jakurai's unintentionally condescending remarks makes for an amusing conclusion. The second stage is a tournament between the three teams that won the first stage. Buster Bros!!! Vs DOTSUITARE-HOMPO vs Matenro Fate once again is in our hands, and this time the choice is between three teams. Cheers for each team echo across the venue, but it's DOTSUITARE-HOMPO who claim victory. The cheering and the screaming reach their climax. At long last, it's time for the final battle with Party of Words. The MC reappears and the screening comes to an end. While the winning division was not my first choice, the result made me very interested to see what a battle between the Kansai team DOTSUITARE-HOMPO and the all-female team Party of Words would look like. You can check out the results via the link below: hypnosismic-movie.com/voting-status/ax2025 You can also check out the results for all the screenings held in Japan here: hypnosismic-movie.com/voting-status/results

    "Uta noâ˜†Prince-sama TABOO NIGHT XXXX"

    After a (small) switch up in the audience between HypMic and Utaâ˜†Pri fans, the MC introduces the next feature and turns the fans' excitement all the way up! This movie is the third theatrical release for Utaâ˜†Pri and contains a full-length live concert as well as a brand-new animation featuring QUARTET NIGHT. The "Uta noâ˜†Prince-samaâ™ª Maji Love" series is a part of the larger Utaâ˜†Pri multimedia franchise, originally a romance visual novel aimed at women. The movie features four members who form the idol unit QUARTET NIGHT: â†’ Reiji Kotobuki â†’ Ranmaru Kurosaki â†’ Ai Mikaze â†’ Camus Setlist: * Jewelful XXXX Seize me if you can (Reiji) Force & Faith (Ranmaru) Wandering in a maze (Ai) Do you know who Iâ€™m (Camus) * Ice Pierrot (Camus) * Zero (Reiji) * Black Panther (Ranmaru) * Am I a fairy or...? (Ai) * The RUN to the RAY (Reiji & Ranmaru) * God Love (Ai & Camus) * TABOO NIGHT XXXX (all members) * JINN-Î©-RAY (all members)
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    The audience cheered and changed the color of their penlights for each idol, and joined in every single idol call. And in perfect Japanese, of course.It was just like being at an idol concert in Japan. After seeing both movies, I was reminded that the love and enthusiasm of fans here rivals â€” or perhaps even surpasses â€” that of fans in Japan. From the happy faces of the fans after the screening, there is no doubt that this passion and love will continue to grow. â€” King Records Editorial Department

    Event outline

    Anime Expo 2025 "HYPNOSISMIC -Division Rap Battle- Movieâ€ & â€œUta noâ˜†Prince-samaâ™ª TABOO NIGHT XXXX" Screening July 5, 12:30 â€“ 2:30 PM | The Novo

    Screening information

    "HYPNOSISMIC -Division Rap Battle- Movieâ€ hypnosismic-movie.com â€œUta noâ˜†Prince-samaâ™ª TABOO NIGHT XXXX" taboonightxxxx.utapri-movie.com Contact information For more information or inquiries, please contact: Shunsuke Souma shunsuke-souma@kingrecords.co.jp

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • The Bandai Namco Music Live Festival returned to Anime Friends 2025, held in SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil from July 3 to 6. This marks the second consecutive year the festival has appeared at South Americaâ€™s largest anime convention, which draws an annual attendance of around 150,000.
  • Bandai Namco Music Live manages labels including Lantis, SUNRISE Music, Kiramune, MoooD Records, and UNIERA, and is home to a diverse roster of artists. On the festivalâ€™s opening day, four acts took the stage: ASH DA HERO, STEREO DIVE FOUNDATION, Nowlu, and MindaRyn.
  • TUfave is excited to announce its new collaboration jewelry collection with the TV anime â€œAttack on Titanâ€. These necklaces (5 designs total) delicately capture the attractiveness of the characters and the series' world, inspired by iconic scenes. Each piece features a simple design centered around a large natural stone, creating "collaboration jewelry for adults" that subtly blends into daily life.

    • Nowlu Kicks Off the Show with Her Anisong Debut

    Nowlu opened the festival with a confident performance that defied the fact it was her first-ever live show. She began with â€œArikaâ€ (GUILTY GEAR STRIVE: DUAL RULERS) and â€œyoinâ€ (Wingman). â€œIâ€™m so happy to have my first live show here in SÃ£o Paulo,â€ she said with a smile, drawing warm cheers. She followed with â€œStuck on youâ€ (More Than a Married Couple, But Not Lovers), creating a calm, intimate moment that brought the crowd together. Her debut ended to enthusiastic applause. Next up was a DJ set by ASH DA HERO member DJ Dhalsim. The crowd couldnâ€™t help but dance as he spun one anisong hit after another: â€œAiâ™¡Scream!â€, â€œBokura wa Ima no Naka deâ€ (Love Live!), â€œShika-iro Daysâ€ (My Deer Friend Nokotan), and â€œHare Hare Yukaiâ€ (The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya). The energy of anisong swept through SÃ£o Paulo, connecting fans across generations.

    â€œBrazil, Iâ€™m back!â€ MindaRyn Returns with a Smile

    MindaRyn took the stage next, returning for a second year in a row. â€œBrazil, Iâ€™m back!â€ she called out with a big smile before launching into a set of three powerful yet gentle songs: â€œDaylightâ€ (Arifureta: From Commonplace to Worldâ€™s Strongest Season 2), â€œShiny Girlâ€ (SHY), and â€œFireworksâ€ (Why Raeliana Ended Up at the Dukeâ€™s Mansion).
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    During her MC segment, she asked, â€œWas anyone here last year? Thanks to those seeing me for the first time, too!â€ connecting warmly with the audience. As part of her world tour Hello New Friends, which began in June 2025, she performs special covers of songs from her label, Lantis. For Brazil, she sang â€œRhapsody of Blue Skyâ€ (Miss Kobayashiâ€™s Dragon Maid, originally by fhÃ¡na) and â€œSparkling Daydreamâ€ (Love, Chunibyo & Other Delusions, originally by ZAQ). She followed with a high-energy rock trio: â€œHIBANAâ€ (Sengoku Youko: The Reformer Siblings Arc), â€œSURVIVEâ€ (Why Raeliana Ended Up at the Dukeâ€™s Mansion), and her breakout hit â€œLike Flamesâ€ (That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime Season 2), which has surpassed 22 million views on YouTube. Her explosive performance had the entire venue fired up.

    STEREO DIVE FOUNDATION: Sound and Vision in Perfect Sync

    STEREO DIVE FOUNDATION (Rãƒ»Oãƒ»N) made his Brazilian debut with a 17-song medley set to anime visuals. Highlights included â€œALPHAâ€ (Moriarty the Patriot), â€œRenegadeâ€ (GANGSTA), and the fan-favorite â€œSTORYSEEKERâ€ (That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime Season 2), which has surpassed 10 million views on YouTube.
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    The set closed with â€œDaisyâ€ (Beyond the Boundary), with the crowd gently swaying their hands in unison. Rãƒ»Oãƒ»N recalled fans in Chile asking, â€œArenâ€™t you coming to Brazil?â€ and now that he had, he understood why. The crowd responded with knowing nods and applause.

    Surprise Collaboration with Ultraman Omega!

    After a brief pause, the word â€œUltramanâ€ appeared on the screen, instantly stirring the crowd. MindaRyn returned to perform â€œBLACK STARâ€ (Ultraman Blazer), followed by an appearance from Ultraman Blazer himself, drawing cheers and excitement.
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    The event then transitioned into the new series Ultraman Omega. ASH performed the opening theme â€œBRIGHT EYES,â€ while MindaRyn and ASH debuted the ending theme â€œMissing Linkâ€ live for the first time. The blend of hero action and rap interplay brought the crowdâ€™s energy to a fever pitch.

    ASH DA HERO Brings the Festival to a Climactic Close

    ASH DA HERO took the stage for the grand finale, joined by Dhalsim (DJ), Sato (bass), and WANI (drums). Kicking off with â€œSuper Sonic,â€ they followed with â€œYELLOW FEVER DANCEâ€ and â€œHankou Seimeiâ€ as the crowd pumped their fists and sang along. They kept the energy high with â€œLA VIDA LOCA,â€ already a live anthem despite being a recent release, then surprised the audience with â€œOctaveâ€ and â€œBeast Mode,â€ insert songs from Blue Lock: Episode Nagi, accompanied by anime footage. After introducing the members, they launched into â€œJudgement,â€ the opening theme for the animeâ€™s second cour. The crowd erupted, singing along as ASH stepped off the stage shouting, â€œSing it, Brazil!â€
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    They closed with a final roar of â€œWe are ASH DA HERO!â€ as ASH triumphantly returned to center stage.

    A Powerful Finale: All Artists Unite

    For the final act, all performers returned to the stage at ASHâ€™s invitation for the first-ever band performance of â€œTrinityâ€ (That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime: The Saga of How the Demon Lord and Dragon Founded a Nation). ASH took on Takuma Terashimaâ€™s part in this rare collaboration, thrilling fans. The concert closed with a group photo and a wave of thunderous applause.
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    The excitement didnâ€™t stop even after the main festival ended. On Friday the 4th, all the performers held a meet-and-greet and Q&A panel. On Saturday the 5th, ASH DA HERO took the stage, followed by STEREO DIVE FOUNDATION and MindaRyn on Sunday the 6th. In its second year, the Bandai Namco Music Live Festival at Anime Friends powered up with even stronger artist Ã— IP collaborations. Alongside powerful performances, the festival featured fan events and previews of new projects, highlighting the full potential of anisong. The anisong wave that swept Brazil in 2024 has firmly taken rootâ€”and is still growing!

    Next Stop: Southeast Asia!

    The Bandai Namco Music Live Festival isnâ€™t just heating up Brazil; itâ€™s heading to Southeast Asia next. The festival will appear at COS-MIC 2025 in Malaysia on September 13, and AniEx 2025 in Bangkok, Thailand on November 22. The anisong excitement born in SÃ£o Paulo is spreading across borders, forging new connections through music. The journey of the Bandai Namco Music Live Festival is only just beginning. item.title: [Honey's Anime Interview] BEYBLADE X Interview with Masahiko Yamazaki, Hisato Takaoka, and Makoto Muraki at the Los Angeles Anime Expo 2025
item.content:encoded:
As part of the BEYBLADE X World Championship, the company behind BEYBLADE held the U.S. National qualifier at Anime Expo 2025 in the Los Angeles Convention Center. Honeyâ€™s Anime had the opportunity to interview Masahiko Yamazaki (Head of Global Beyblade Business), Hisato Takaoka (General Manager of Beyblade), and Makoto Muraki (Specialist on the Beyblade Design Team). Letâ€™s see what they had to say about BEYBLADE Xâ€™s first tournament appearance at AX!

Takaoka
Yamazaki
Muraki
Honey-Chan
Interview with the BEYBLADE Team
[gray-hex-decoration]
Why did you choose Anime Expo as the venue for the U.S. National qualifier? What goes into organizing an event of this scale here?
BEYBLADE launched in Japan in 1999, and in the U.S. in 2000. That means it has been 25 years since BEYBLADE first arrived in America. Last year was our first time bringing BEYBLADE to Anime Expo and we were very, very surprised and excited to find so many adult fans here. We have always believed the potential of American fans and community, and seeing their passion firsthand was a very great opportunity for us. Thatâ€™s why we wanted to return and hold the tournament at this year's event. BEYBLADE started just as a toy, but weâ€™ve been aiming towards making it an entertainment sport, thatâ€™s why we thought about Los Angeles, the city of entertainment. Anime Expo is a very, very huge event so, in line with our branchâ€™s story, this is a very suitable opportunity and a suitable event at AX. If you had the chance to come here during the morning (Saturday, July 5, 2025) there were so many people in line, we were not expecting so many fans to show up! Last year, BEYBLADE was here, but this year is the first time that weâ€™ve held a tournament. We could not have imagined the number of people who attended. We were pleasantly surprised and very impressed with the number of attendees.
What are you hoping that fans take away from this event, or what were you expecting to show fans by holding this tournament here at AX?
From what Iâ€™ve seen, thereâ€™s a great opportunity to further grow and support adult tournaments in the U.S. I want to give hope that in the future, we will have more and more events for the American fans. While at the booth, I wondered why 200, or 300 people had gathered here, staying all the time around the stage area; it got me thinking that maybe this is a very, very rare opportunity to witness an official BEYBLADE tournament.
I wanted fans to take away the experience of an official tournament. I hope that those people who participated in the Anime Expo Tournament, go back to their hometowns and do the same as they did here. We formally introduced how to participate in a BEYBLADE tournament, showed them not only the format, but the experience, and how it goes after you lose or win a match, where you shake hands, etc. Thatâ€™s the experience I hope they take from this event.
After seeing the popularity of the BEYBLADE X tournament in Anime Expo, are you planning on coming back to AX next year or maybe plan on holding other official tournaments in other conventions across the U.S.?
Yes, as BEYBLADE X we plan to come to Anime Expo next year. We hope to expand with other tournaments or activities, as well as participate in other major U.S. conventions, working together with Hasbro, our U.S. partner.
With BEYBLADE X growing in popularity, whatâ€™s your vision for the expansion of the franchise in the next decade? Do you see it expanding into things like virtual or augmented reality battles, or is the focus more on growing physical product availability, especially here in the U.S.?
Seeing that there are many new technologies like AI, AR, or VR as you mentioned, in the case of BEYBLADE it had a weird introduction into the metaverse world through Roblox. Right now, nearly 40 million visitors from around the world have joined the BEYBLADE world on Roblox. I can see that technology is important, but from what I can see the most important thing is the community. BEYBLADE fans are encouraged to enjoy the brand in many ways, so it has great potential to cultivate a community no matter what technology it expands to. But weâ€™ve committed to grow the community rather than focusing on introducing the brand to new technology.
Why did you choose Roblox as the â€œcommunity builderâ€ for BEYBLADE?
In Japan, Roblox is not really popular yet, but in the U.S.A, as well as other parts of Asia it's really popular. BEYBLADEsâ€™ strength is that they can provide a physical experience, at the same time, this is our weakness. We want fans to enjoy BEYBLADE globally, but as of right now, Roblox is the answer the fans have created. And the fantastic thing is that you can play it from anywhere. [Takaoka proceeds to take out his phone, which is already online on Roblox and actively spectating a BEYBLADE match between real people that are online at that moment]
The players of that BEYBLADE world in Roblox, the total of Japanese players is maybe around 5% but the other 95% are from all over the world; number one is currently Thailand, followed by Mexico and the U.S.A. That's why we embraced Roblox, since itâ€™s a global platform that surpasses the barriers and restrictions of our physical limitations.
When designing parts for BEYBLADE X with competitive players in mind, how do you strike a balance between performance, durability, and customization? Is one prioritized more than the others, or is it always a compromise?
Those three elements you mentioned are very, very important. First of all, BEYBLADE X is a product that can be enjoyed by children and adults, so our priority is safety. At the same time, it has to be truly thrilling and fun to play. Although it seems at odds with safety the features that make the game excitingâ€”like high-speed, intense collisions are essential for our products so it is a big challenge for us to pursue both aspects. We try not to have tradeoffs or compromises, they try to deliver all those points at the highest possible â€œlevelâ€, This is something we really take care of when thinking about new model designs.
As a competitive game, BEYBLADE must often introduce different "battle strategies". I see BEYBLADE X has a gimmick called "X-dash" Could you walk me through how you come up with these strategies?
BEYBLADE X physical contact is really important. â€œPhysical contactâ€ is the base keyword in the company, so everyone keeps it in mind when creating the product. If it goes faster, would it be interesting? If it falls apart, will it be interesting? Those kinds of unique ideas are always brought forward by the team and we bring it to life as a demo product by the design team to test it out. After everyone has experienced it and it makes sense as a strategy, then the idea will move on to the next level until it makes it to the actual product. One thing weâ€™re always taking care of is that we donâ€™t create only an idea, but also create a demo product to test it out within the team.
As for battle gimmicks like the X-Dash, so far what has been the most challenging or interesting gimmick that you have created?
3rd generation BEYBLADE Burst. This was the first time that the toy would be torn apart, breaking into pieces. That gimmick introduced in the 3rd generation was challenging because the point was for them to break apart on purpose, but also you should be able to put it back together. On top of that, we had to achieve for it to spin super fast and all the pieces would fly out all over the place, so safety was a challenge. Before this model, the arena did not have the guard piece, so we had to come up with the arena barrier too.
Now that you have seen the popularity of BEYBLADE X in Anime Expo, and of course, Anime Expo caters to an Otaku culture, do you have in mind any collaboration with some big anime title? For example, a series of toys inspired by big IPs?
In Japan, weâ€™ve had experience collaborating with celebrities and sports groups. We wonâ€™t deny any future collaborations with any anime IP. We have already collaborated with major IPs like Star Wars and Marvel featuring characters like Skywalker or Spiderman, we even have a collaboration with FC Barcelona, a legendary European multi-sports club based in Catalonia.
I want to ask you all for your personal experience watching the popularity of the BEYBLADE X booth and seeing all the fans there as well as the competitive U.S. Bey community playing in the tournament. Has anything surprised you? Has the U.S. player base inspired you in any way? Howâ€™s the US community different from the Japanese community? Any personal feelings that youâ€™d like to share about your experience at Anime Expo and the BEYBLADE Championship?
As I expected, United States fans are really full of emotion. Most of the Americanã€€fans are shouting â€œWoo, I did it! I did it!â€. I like this style of celebrating, it's something I am really glad to see, hahaha.
During BEYBLADEâ€™s panel event at AX, we played the first episode of our new anime season. The fans there were very very excited and had a good reaction. But we not only talked about the animation, we also talked about BEYBLADE as a product and the community was very curious about how we design our toys, about the making process. It gave me the impression that the U.S. fans are extremely curious about BEYBLADE, so I enjoyed their reaction to our panel.
When I saw the participants of the tournaments and noticed the kind of Beys that they use I thought their selections were interesting. Usually, when you compete in tournaments, the ultimate goal should be to win, right? But seeing the U.S. participants, they are using the BEYBLADEs that they really like, ones that they have emotional attachments to. The ratio is a lot higher in the U.S. than in Japan. The way that fans enjoy BEYBLADE X here in the U.S. is wider, so thatâ€™s the point of view I gained from this experience and I will take it into consideration for future product design.
The passion and enthusiasm surrounding BEYBLADE X at Anime Expo 2025 was undeniable. It's clear that BEYBLADE continues to evolve as more than just a toy, itâ€™s a global phenomenon fueled by community, creativity, and competition. With plans to return and expand further into U.S. events, the future of BEYBLADE is spinning faster than ever!
